title: Native Americans for kids: Cherokee, Apache, Navajo, Iroquois and Sioux

options.label: C

options.label: B

title: What it's like to be a Muslim in America - Dalia Mogahed
Is it normal to talk to yourself?

multiple-choice.question: What does self-talk refer to according to psychologists?

options.label: A
options.text: Personal conversations and reflections throughout the day

options.label: B
options.text: Mental imagery or recalling facts and figures

options.label: C
options.text: Conversations with imaginary friends

options.label: D
options.text: Outer speech directed toward others

multiple-choice.question: Why do some people engage in more self-talk than others?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a higher level of anxiety

options.label: B
options.text: They are naturally more introspective

options.label: C
options.text: Their brain chemistry is different

options.label: D
options.text: They have been diagnosed with a mental health disorder

multiple-choice.question: How does self-talk impact attitude and performance?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no effect

options.label: B
options.text: It can decrease focus and self-esteem

options.label: C
options.text: It can increase focus, boost self-esteem, and help tackle everyday tasks

options.label: D
options.text: It only impacts physical performance

multiple-choice.question: What is distanced self-talk and how can it be beneficial?

options.label: A
options.text: Distanced self-talk is when you speak to yourself as if you're talking to another person. This type of self- talk can be especially beneficial for reducing stress.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a form of meditation that helps with focus

options.label: C
options.text: It's a type of cognitive behavioral therapy used to treat anxiety and depression

options.label: D
options.text: It's a technique used in public speaking to improve confidence

multiple-choice.question: What is the connection between negative self-talk and mental health?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no connection

options.label: B
options.text: Negative self-talk only affects physical health

options.label: C
options.text: High levels of negative self-talk are often predictive of anxiety, and can lead to more intense feelings of depression.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a symptom of a more serious underlying condition

title: How tall can a tree grow? - Valentin Hammoudi

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The coastal regions of the Pacific Northwest

options.label: D
options.text: The forests of Oregon

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of phloem sap in a tree's growth process?

options.label: A
options.text: To transport nutrients absorbed through the roots to the rest of the tree

options.label: B
options.text: To generate heat for the tree's metabolic processes

options.label: C
options.text: To provide structural support for the tree's branches and leaves

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the opening and closing of stomata in the leaves

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary force driving xylem sap upwards in a tree?

options.label: A
options.text: Transpiration pull

options.label: B
options.text: Root pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Capillary action

options.label: D
options.text: Osmotic movement

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the model that explains why trees have limited heights, even under ideal growing conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydraulic ascension hypothesis

options.label: B
options.text: Turgor tension theory

options.label: C
options.text: Photosynthetic constraint concept

options.label: D
options.text: The hydraulic limitation hypothesis

title: Why should you read Toni Morrison's "Beloved"? - Yen Pham

multiple-choice.question: What is the main theme of "Beloved"?

options.label: A
options.text: The ghost haunting the house at 124 Bluestone Road.

options.label: B
options.text: Slavery's destructive effects on all forms of love.

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of family unity in the face of trauma.

options.label: D
options.text: African-American history and the role of love.

multiple-choice.question: In "Beloved," how does Toni Morrison explore black identities?

options.label: A
options.text: By focusing on characters' forbidden affections.

options.label: B
options.text: By examining how characters are blind to the love they possess.

options.label: C
options.text: Through characters who challenge social conventions in matters of love.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What does Sethe struggle with after escaping enslavement?

options.label: A
options.text: Coping with her past and healing from trauma.

options.label: B
options.text: Living an unlivable life due to societal shunning.

options.label: C
options.text: Acceptance of the ghost haunting her home.

options.label: D
options.text: Reconnecting with her lost family members.

multiple-choice.question: How does Morrison convey the trauma of slavery in "Beloved"?

options.label: A
options.text: By referring to enslaved people as animals with monetary value.

options.label: B
options.text: Through characters' coping mechanisms, such as dissociation or remaining mired in their pasts.

options.label: C
options.text: By blending perspectives and timelines, exposing conflicting viewpoints on reality.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What does "Beloved" urge readers to consider?

options.label: A
options.text: The destructiveness of hate.

options.label: B
options.text: The redeeming power of love.

options.label: C
options.text: The responsibility we bear to heed the voices of the past.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: Can you outsmart this logical fallacy? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon causes people to perceive statements with more conditions as more believable?

options.label: A
options.text: The conjunction fallacy

options.label: B
options.text: The disjunction fallacy

options.label: C
options.text: The induction fallacy

options.label: D
options.text: The deduction fallacy

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following best describes the main idea of the video transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of understanding probability and statistics in everyday life.

options.label: B
options.text: The role of math education in shaping career choices.

options.label: C
options.text: How our intuition can mislead us when making quick decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: The benefits of studying probability and statistics for personal growth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why adding more details to a story can make it seem more plausible?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the story more specific and concrete.

options.label: B
options.text: It aligns better with our preconceived expectations.

options.label: C
options.text: It appeals to our sense of narrative coherence.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the overall probability of the story being true.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following scenarios would be LESS likely to occur based on the information provided in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker.

options.label: B
options.text: Lucy is a portrait artist who doesn't play poker.

options.label: C
options.text: Lucy is not a portrait artist, but she enjoys playing poker.

options.label: D
options.text: Lucy is a portrait artist and has no interest in playing poker.

multiple-choice.question: What does the video transcript suggest about how people make quick decisions when presented with multiple options?

options.label: A
options.text: People tend to look for shortcuts and choose what seems plausible.

options.label: B
options.text: People always consider all available information before making a decision.

options.label: C
options.text: People are generally aware of the conjunction fallacy and avoid it.

options.label: D
options.text: People's intuition is always accurate in quick decision-making scenarios.

title: Einstein's twin paradox explained - Amber Stuver

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between an object's speed through space and its perceived rate of time passing compared to an unmoving observer?

options.label: A
options.text: The faster an object moves through space, the faster it moves through time.

options.label: B
options.text: The faster an object moves through space, the slower it moves through time.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no relationship between an object's speed through space and its perceived rate of time passing.

options.label: D
options.text: The faster an object moves through space, the more time passes normally.

multiple-choice.question: What does the Lorentz factor represent in terms of special relativity?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the distance light can travel in a year.

options.label: B
options.text: It quantifies the relationship between an object's speed through space and its perceived rate of time passing compared to an unmoving observer.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a measure of length contraction for moving objects.

options.label: D
options.text: It measures the difference between an inertial reference frame and a non-inertial one.

multiple-choice.question: According to the video transcript, what is the "Twin Paradox"?

options.label: A
options.text: The phenomenon where both twins age at different rates due to their relative velocities.

options.label: B
options.text: The contradiction between Stella's outbound journey and her return journey when considering time dilation.

options.label: C
options.text: The difference in age between Terra and Stella when they meet back on Earth after 23 years apart.

options.label: D
options.text: The concept that time passes differently for objects moving at different speeds through space.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the light-year distance used to describe Stella's journey?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a measure of the distance between Earth and the destination star.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the maximum distance that light can travel in one year.

options.label: C
options.text: It is used to calculate the age difference between Terra and Stella when they meet back on Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a unit of measurement for comparing different velocities in space.

multiple-choice.question: How do the twins use light bursts to resolve their disagreement about which of them ages more quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: By observing the frequency at which the other twin sends light bursts as time passes for them.

options.label: B
options.text: By comparing the ages of both twins when they meet back on Earth after 23 years apart.

options.label: C
options.text: By discussing the concepts of special relativity and their implications.

options.label: D
options.text: By conducting an experiment in which one twin remains on Earth while the other travels to a distant star.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Black

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Soak up the rays like a sponge

options.label: B
options.text: Reflect them like a mirror

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

multiple-choice.question: At what time of day is the sun's light usually at its strongest, making it more likely to cause sunburn?

options.label: A
options.text: Between 6 AM and 10 AM

options.label: B
options.text: Between 10 AM and 2 PM

options.label: C
options.text: Between 2 PM and 4 PM

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is one important thing to remember when applying sunscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: Apply it only on exposed skin

options.label: B
options.text: Put on lots of sunscreen at least ten minutes before going outside

options.label: C
options.text: Reapply sunscreen after swimming or getting sweaty

options.label: D
